sections.narration: Welcome to our lesson on Appomattox & Lincoln's Assassination. War's End (1865). You'll experience this story through the eyes of Daniel, age 16, Union soldier, 1865.

I'm Daniel, sixteen years old, and I've been a Union soldier for two years. I enlisted in 1863 after the Emancipation Proclamation. The war had become a crusade to end slavery, and I wanted to be part of it. By early 1865, the war's end was approaching.
sections.key_takeaway: I'm Daniel, sixteen years old, and I've been a Union soldier for two years.

sections.narration: April 9, 1865. Palm Sunday. We woke to news that Confederate forces blocked Lee's retreat route. Lee's army was surrounded.
visuals: Chapter title: Palm Sunday at Appomattox

sections.narration: April 12. Three days after the surrender, Confederate soldiers formally laid down their weapons. I was there, part of the Union honor guard. About 28,000 Confederate soldiers marched between two lines of Union troops.
visuals: Chapter title: The Armies Say Goodbye

sections.narration: April 14, 1865. Good Friday. Five days after Appomattox, the war essentially over. President Lincoln was in good spirits.

Vice President Andrew Johnson became president on April 15. Johnson was a Tennessee Democrat who'd remained loyal to the Union. But he lacked Lincoln's vision, compassion, and political skill. Lincoln had been planning "Reconstruction"—the process of bringing Southern states back into the Union and transforming the South from a slave society to a free one.
visuals: Chapter title: What Might Have Been
sections.key_takeaway: Vice President Andrew Johnson became president on April 15.

sections.narration: In this lesson, we explored Appomattox & Lincoln's Assassination through 5 chapters. Key concepts included: Appomattox Court House, Ulysses S. Grant, Robert E. Lee, Generous Terms.
